author: R Vimal Kumar
text:
A team of archaeologists have found a seemingly rare statue of ‘Nandi’ with Tamil script engraved on it, from the outskirts of Tirupur city.

The granite sculpture was found near a centuries-old temple at Chinnaariyapatti.

The temple itself remaining neglected for many decades.

After reports appeared about the architecturally-rich temple in The Hindu in September 2015, some conservationists restored it to an extent.

“A Nandi with Tamil script is one of the rarest things in the entire South India. The statue is of 90 cm long and 50 cm high, with eight lines of Tamil script,” said S. Ravikumar, one of the archaeologists of the Veerarajendran Archaeological ad Historical Research Centre here.R. Poongundran, a former Assistant Director of the State Archaeological Department, who deciphered the script on the statue, said the lines indicated that an official who was in charge of the area about 1,000 years back had erected the structure.

The lines say that the sculpture was set up to thank God for curing some disease in the locality.

The practice of erecting animal sculpture was prevalent in some villages of Kongunadu, said Mr. Poongundran adding that it was for the first time Tamil script was found on such sculptures.
title: Rare ‘Nandi’ found near temple
